text: <@U0P1VU0QG|ikruiper> has joined the channel

Hello <@U1ENXTQRL> regarding 1, an auditor could or could not be enrolled in the system, the idea is to have flexibility to not force the auditors to be participants of the network. The auditor will request access to a preK from the preK tree according to his jurisdiction. That key will allow the auditor to derivate keys to decrypt attributes from TCerts if the affiliation of that TCert falls into the auditor jurisdiction
this also means that auditors don't need interaction with validators

regarding 2, attributes are encrypted in a way that allows his owner to grant access to see the actual value or to grant access to only make questions against the value (somethink like: is the value of this attribute “X”, and the answer will be yes, or no, without revealing the actual value of the attribute)
hope it makes sense, if you have additional questions please feel free to ask :slightly_smiling_face:
Thanks <@U0XQX3U9G> !
Well, #2 sounds indeed like a "zero-knowledge proof", although I'm not acquainted with the implementation details to tell if we can formally call it that. In any case, that's a nice feature.
I agree with you, is not formally zero knowledge, but you can think of it as similar
:+1::skin-tone-3:

<@U11MANG9G|jonathanlevi> pinned their PDF <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/jonathanlevi/F1RQTACSZ/2016-07-13_membershipservicesinhyperledgerfabric_part2.pdf|2016-07-13_MembershipServicesInHyperledgerFabric_Part2.pdf> to this channel.

Carlos:
1. What Diego said!
2. Take another look at slide 10...
Thanks! Yes, that was the slide that raised the question originally.
That + the code will give you the sense of how it's done....
Any direct links to the code? :slightly_smiling_face:
The idea is that the verifier receives the encryption key for the particular attribute within a particular TCert.
<@U1ENXTQRL>: the code for point 2 (verify-only attribute access) is not on github yet
I see.
Well... to be clear, we currently don't encrypt attributes (by default, etc.)
There is some part that is missing from the slides which I won't cover - but effectively,
the verifier encrypts what *they believe the attribute value to be*.
(maybe that's where/why you got the ZK-like impression. Just to be clear: "this is not zero-knowledge")
exactly, but the encryption code is already on github, not the verify only access
OK.

Hey guys, by the way... do you understand _Key_ _Agreement_ _TCerts_?  I'm having a hard time grasping it.

If you are able to explain it "like I'm 5". I'd truly appreciate it.
sure
please take a look at the diagram in this page (the one explaining key agreement with colors)
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffie%E2%80%93Hellman_key_exchange>
that is the best explaination of key agreement I found
once you get that, a TCert for key agreement is just a TCert with a public key for key agreement
Thanks Diego, I'll check that, and then I'll come back with more questions (new ones I hope) :sweat_smile:
sure!
<@U0KM61BCP|cbf> has joined the channel
Alright, I think I got Diffie Hellman at a high level. The diagram with colors is really helpful...
Now Key Agreement TCerts implement a key agreement algorithm like this?
Or does it only have a public key so the involved parties compute the resulting shared key by themselves?
the second statement :slightly_smiling_face:
Understood.
Thank you.
you are welcome!
Now, does this TCert public key have a corresponding private key that generated it?
it is the same as for the signature TCert
the private key is generated by the client using the key derivation
so, when the client wants to use the TCert, if it needs the private key it will derive it

Hi guys, I'm enjoying reading this conversation.  Is there any more formal documentation about this stuff?  In particular, it would be nice to look at things and see if you can get formal guarantees.  You all are talking about things like "zero-knowledge-like-things" and "sounds like a zero-knowledge proof", and it would be nice to see what exact formal guarantees you could get from a system.  It would probably be useful to formally prove some of these statements and show exactly what you get.
I agree, we need to do that
I would like to do that
<@U0RD1ALMV>: to be fair/clear, this is not a "zero knowledge" construct (hence my ref to Slide 10). I have (re)clarified above.
But (more?) documentation is certainly needed!
Yes indeed!
And many, many diagrams :slightly_smiling_face:

<@U11MANG9G>: Right, I saw the comment.  I should have clarified that I meant this in a broader sense of the protocol.  I just saw this as perhaps the most glaring example of people looking for cryptographic properties and not being exactly sure of what they were getting.
yes, I see it from that point too
<@U0RD1ALMV>: Glad to have you here with us!
<@U1RJ0M1EC|voodoo> has joined the channel
<@U1RSUUJ57|karsellami> has joined the channel
